titleStmt.title: The Welshmans answer, to that false petition which was printed of her reputation, and protestation made in her vindication of her defamed reputation. Written by me, Shon op Shones, by the consent of her cosins of creat qualitie; Wilham Powell, Shonny Morgan, and her cosin Cadwalladore, and her cosin Criffen, and her cosin Shenkin. Cots plutter a nailes, if her tid put know how tid so apuse us, her would would have them py their long tusks, and pumble her nose soundly.
titleStmt.author: Shones, Shon ap.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE WELSHMANS ANSWER, TO THAT FALSE PETITION Which was printed of her Reputation, and Prote≈øtation made in her Vindication of her defamed Reputation.
Written by me, Shon op Shones, by the con≈øent of her Co≈øins of creat qualitie; Wilham Powell, Shonny Morgan, and her Co≈øin Cadwalladore, and her Co≈øin Criffen, and her Co≈øin Shenkin.
Cots plutter a nailes, if her tid put know how tid ≈øo apu≈øe us, her would would have them py their long tusks, and pumble her no≈øe ≈øoundly.

div.head: THE WELSHMANS REPLICATION, To a Petition and Prote≈øtation made in vindication of her defamed Reputation. Ann. Dom. 1641.
div.p:
FOr, whereas to her creat di≈øgrace and defamation, a Petition and Prote≈øtation hath bin made and framed py idle and frantick wits, tat reflects not only upon her own proper per≈øon, but her whole Country, as well of te Shentility as Commonalty, which her cannot hear in ≈øuch deriding and ≈øheering manner cried up and down te ≈øtreets, but
her was inforced to vindicate her reputation therein publikely by writing, and if not by te ≈øame prevented, it may in time comming be an occa≈øion of creater trouble.

Put it is not her particular ca≈øe only, to pe apu≈øed and ≈øcandalized py ≈øuch Pamphlets, put te Autors thereof have pin ≈øo prodigall, as to apu≈øe not only her ≈øelf, and te re≈øt of her co≈øins Countrimen, put al≈øo tivers te≈øerving members of te Engli≈øh ≈øtate as well creat per≈øons as lower, who≈øe di≈øpo≈øitions have not agreed to every ones humour; yea, they have not pin a≈øhamed to apu≈øe her King, queen, and Prince, put Nobility and High Court of Parliament, which if they pe ≈øuffered without puni≈øhment, ≈øuch danger may ari≈øe poth to City and Country, as was hard to appea≈øe.

The≈øe foul apu≈øes in printing ≈øuch pooks, under colour either of Parliament proceedings; or Iri≈øh Newes, hath produced a creat ≈øcandal over te
whole Kingdome, which her hears is al≈øo taken notice of py Outlandi≈øh Nations. Her al≈øo was never read ≈øuch printing in former Parliaments without power of the ≈øame, put now poor fellows and pretended writers pends their indeavours to devi≈øe ≈øcandalous pooks, pe they of what Nature or qualitie ≈øoever, pe it of never ≈øuch ill con≈øequence, be it again≈øt never ≈øo creat and venerable Pi≈øhits. Is there put te lea≈øt thing done in Parliament, nay put a tale or thought of ≈øuch a thing of proceeding again≈øt any man what≈øoever, pe he Lord or Peer, if not py them fancied, put pre≈øent a pook is made of them, if they have put te name of the per≈øon, it was to her a cood rea≈øon to make and create a Pamphlet of them. Put ple≈ø≈øe me God, this is not all, her tiveli≈øh and mortal enemies perform; te waters are acquainted with the affections of the people, how they ≈øtand inclined, who was ready to take
part with her foes and who not; py which ≈øuch remote enemies tat have intelligencer in her Kings Provinces, may know te better how to compa≈øs their de≈øignes in agitation again≈øt her Per≈øon and Country, which is of creat advantage to her enemies poth publike and private.

Her was therefore earne≈øtly intreat, tat this her writing, ≈øhewing her intention to defend her reputation may be re≈øpected, tat ≈øuch pooks which tend only to te ≈øtirring up ≈øtrife and di≈ø≈øention, may not again pe ritten or publi≈øhed to her di≈øcrace and di≈øcredit. Her affections are no wayes tardy to any thing tat may prove profitable and nece≈ø≈øary to her advancement in her Country and te Engli≈øh people in their Britannicall glory and fame. Her indeavors ≈øhall alwaies comply with her cood King and his high Court of Parliament in in ≈øetling of peace and quietne≈ø≈øe, which her was ever apide in all her
Kings nations, her ≈øhall pe willing to loo≈øe her own dear per≈øon and coods in any ≈øervice when her was commanded in maintainance thereof. Her was ≈øen≈øible with cood feeling, tat te authors of the≈øe pooks are ≈øheering and pabling poor rogues, de≈øirous in their tiveli≈øh works to plea≈øe the times, pe it crooked or ≈øtraight. Her is ≈øo well literated in latter examples, tat py examples her can make manife≈øt what her ≈øay, and defend it to pe cood.

Te troubles petween England and Scotland, which nation hath ≈øince approved them≈øelves loyall and faithfull ≈øubjects to their cood King, and tat all they did in taking up Armes, was onely in defence of their Religion, Lawes, and Liperties of tat Kingdome, which tiveli≈øh per≈øons ≈øeeked to te≈øtroy. And during the≈øe troubles, what evill pooks and ≈øcandalous papers were printed and publi≈øhed in di≈øgrace; and contrariwi≈øe,
what pooks were devi≈øed in prai≈øe and honor of te Pi≈øhits, and others in creat places of Authoritie in Church and State, that were incendaries in tho≈øe di≈ø≈øentions. And ≈øince the meeting of this ple≈ø≈øed Societie, tat there is by the wi≈øedome thereof a Peace concluded petween poth Countries, her perceives contrary pooks made in honour of the Scots, and defamation of malefactors, py which her well ≈øees the≈øe fellowes will do any thing, right or wrong. Put her will ≈øay no more put this, if her de≈øires pe not py this writing con≈øidered, her was intend in humility to pe a Petitioner in pehalf of her ≈øelf and Country, to the Parliament for relief, and puni≈øhing te Autors of the≈øe abu≈øes.
